byline.original: Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 23. -- Doubt is now expressed that the government will decree amnesty for exiles of the Sao Paulo, inasmuch as there are no criminal charges against them, and it is argued that amnesty is unnecessary.
docs.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 23. -- Doubt is now expressed that the government will decree amnesty for exiles of the Sao Paulo, inasmuch as there are no criminal charges against them, and it is argued that amnesty is unnecessary.

headline.main: BRAZIL DOUBTS AMNESTY.; Move Is Said to Be Unnecessary for Exiles.

byline.original: Special Cable to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: DALLAS, Texas, March 23. -- More is to be expected from the working out of closer cooperation between the republics of North and South America at the coming conference at Montevideo, General J.G. Harbord told the Pan-American Medical Congress today,...
docs.lead_paragraph: DALLAS, Texas, March 23. -- More is to be expected from the working out of closer cooperation between the republics of North and South America at the coming conference at Montevideo, General J.G. Harbord told the Pan-American Medical Congress today, than from, all the disarmament conferences which have occupied the State Department and diplomats since the armament conference in Washington.
docs.abstract: Pan-Amer Med Cong to celebrate anniversary of birth Dec 3

headline.main: URGES FREE TRADE FOR THE AMERICAS; General Harbord, in Address to Medical Congress, Advocates Economic Union. DAY SET TO HONOR FINLAY Birth of Yellow Fever Conqueror to Be Celebrated on Dec. 3 -- McReynolds Named President.

headline.main: BRAZILIAN LEADERS PLAN A NEW STATE; Autonomist Party Would Try Socialistic Experiment in Federal District. TO CONTROL EMPLOYMENT Parliament Would Have a Tech- nical House and Science Would Be Commandeered.

byline.original: Special Correspondence, THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: A statement of the Department of Commerce on the source or destination by countries of the gold imported or exported during February shows that the month's total gold imports of $30,381,313 came from thirty-three different countries, while gold...
docs.lead_paragraph: A statement of the Department of Commerce on the source or destination by countries of the gold imported or exported during February shows that the month's total gold imports of $30,381,313 came from thirty-three different countries, while gold exports, aggregating $21,520,552, went to ten.
docs.abstract: Rept for Feb on exports and imports

headline.main: $30,381,313 OF GOLD IMPORTED IN FEBRUARY; Shipments Were Received From 33 Nations -- $21,520,552 Sent to Ten Countries.

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The only grand division to which exports from the United States increased last month as compared with a year ago was South America.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The only grand division to which exports from the United States increased last month as compared with a year ago was South America.

headline.main: OUR EXPORTS ROSE TO SOUTH AMERICA; February Total of $8,131,419 Was $713,667 More Than In Same Month of 1932. BUT EUROPE TOOK MOST Figure Was $51,099,238 Out of $101,530,302 -- Imports From Six Countries Increased.

byline.original: Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, March 30 -- The Uruguayan political situation, which has been tense for several weeks, reached a crisis today when President Gabriel Terra was forced to abandon Government House, moving the executive office and Ministry of the Interior...
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, March 30 -- The Uruguayan political situation, which has been tense for several weeks, reached a crisis today when President Gabriel Terra was forced to abandon Government House, moving the executive office and Ministry of the Interior to the central barracks of the Montevideo Fire Department.

headline.main: Uruguay's President Moves to Firehouse; Troops Control Capital as Revolt Looms

byline.original: By JOHN W. WHITE.Special Cable to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, March 31. -- President Gabriel Terra of Uruguay dissolved the Uruguayan Congress and National Administrative Council, assumed dictatorial powers and appointed a junta of eight notable civilians to assist him in administrative functions...
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, March 31. -- President Gabriel Terra of Uruguay dissolved the Uruguayan Congress and National Administrative Council, assumed dictatorial powers and appointed a junta of eight notable civilians to assist him in administrative functions until such time as the Constitutional Assembly which he plans to call reforms the Constitution and sets up a new administration.

headline.main: PRESIDENT SEIZES POWER IN URUGUAY; Dr. Terra Ousts Council and Names Junta to Help Him Rule as Dictator. FOES OF PLAN ARRESTED Ex-President Baltasar Blum, Friend of Woodrow Wilson, Reported a Suicide.

byline.original: By JOHN W. WHITE.Special Cable to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, April 1. -- Highly censored dispatches from Montevideo, Uruguay, coatinue to insist that President Gabriel Terra has the support of the armed forces of Uruguay and also of the police, and that his intervention in all public offices...
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, April 1. -- Highly censored dispatches from Montevideo, Uruguay, coatinue to insist that President Gabriel Terra has the support of the armed forces of Uruguay and also of the police, and that his intervention in all public offices gives him control of the capital at least.
docs.abstract: Terra bans provincial assemblies, replacing them with Fed interventors; issues 11 other decrees; opponents flee to legations

headline.main: TERRA BROADENS HIS DICTATORSHIP; Bans Uruguay's Provincial Assemblies, Replacing Them With Federal Interventors. ISSUES 11 OTHER DECREES Opponents Flee to Legations -- Na- tion Shocked on Learning of Suicide of Brum.

byline.original: Special Cable to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: JAPAN'S announcement that she intends to withdraw from the League is the second notice of the kind before that body. Mexico served notice last December, and her withdrawal will become effective after two years unless she rescinds her action.
docs.lead_paragraph: JAPAN'S announcement that she intends to withdraw from the League is the second notice of the kind before that body. Mexico served notice last December, and her withdrawal will become effective after two years unless she rescinds her action.
docs.abstract: Reduced to 55 by withdrawal of Japan and Mex; rev of conditions of membership and previous withdrawals; list of members

headline.main: TWO MEMBERS PREPARE TO QUIT THE LEAGUE; Loss of Japan and Mexico in 1935 Would Reduce the Enrolment to Fifty-five
